C. some adult workers which are specially fed to breed.
D. Developing nymph nurtured as secondary reproductive
questions.explanation: Termite colonies can replace their primary reproductives (king and queen) with secondary reproductives that develop from nymphs specifically nurtured for this role.

questions.question: The male cockroach differs from the female by having
questions.explanation: Male cockroaches possess a pair of anal styles, which are absent in females. Both sexes have mandibles, spiracles, and cerci.

questions.question: The crayfish is an arthropod because
options: A. its body consists of a cephalothorax and an abdomen
B. It has a pair each of antennae and antennules
C. every segment of its body carries a pair of appendages
D. its body is covered with an exoskeleton made of chitin.
questions.explanation: The possession of a chitinous exoskeleton is the fundamental characteristic shared by all arthropods, including the crayfish.

questions.question: In the life history of a butterfly, destruction of crops ls caused by the
questions.explanation: The larval stage of a butterfly, known as a caterpillar, is the main feeding stage and causes damage to crops by consuming leaves.

questions.question: Insects and millipede have many features in common EXCEPT
questions.explanation: While insects typically have compound eyes, most millipedes have simple eyes or are blind. Both share an exoskeleton, jointed appendages, and a segmented body.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common characteristic of crustaceans?
options: A. Possession of a pair of antennae
B. Possession of two pairs of antennae.
C. Each segment has a pair of walking legs
D. Four pairs of walking legs on the cephalothorax
questions.explanation: Crustaceans are unique among arthropods for having two pairs of antennae.

questions.question: The pedipalpi in spiders are used for
questions.explanation: Pedipalps are appendages near the mouth of a spider used for sensing, but their primary function is for grasping and manipulating prey.

questions.question: Which of the labelled parts is used for feeling?
questions.explanation: Part 1 is the antenna, which is the main sensory organ for feeling and sensing the environment.

questions.question: The structure labeled 2 is the
questions.explanation: Part 2 is the labial palp, a mouthpart that aids in feeding by sensing and handling food.

questions.question: The function of maxillipeds in crayfish is to aid
questions.explanation: Maxillipeds are specialized appendages in crustaceans that are used to help manipulate and process food, assisting in feeding.

questions.question: Which Of the following is metamorphosis?
questions.explanation: A termite undergoes incomplete metamorphosis, while the others listed undergo complete metamorphosis.

questions.question: The butterfly Is of great economic importance because
options: A. of its use in scientific studies
B. it sucks nectar from flowers
C. It adds to the beauty of the environment
D. It pollinates flowers of crops and other plants.
questions.explanation: The most significant economic importance of butterflies is their role as pollinators of many plants, including crops.

questions.question: The part used for feeling is labelled
questions.explanation: Part I is the antenna, the primary sensory organ for touch and other environmental cues.

questions.question: The mouth part of the Insect is adapted for
questions.explanation: Based on the diagram of the grasshopper, its mouthparts (mandibles) are adapted for biting and chewing plant material.

questions.question: Which of the following insects lays its eggs In horny, purse-like cases?
questions.explanation: A cockroach lays its eggs in a tough, protective capsule called an ootheca.

questions.question: The group of insects that undergoes complete metamorphosis Is
questions.explanation: Houseflies, beetles, and butterflies all undergo complete metamorphosis, which includes the larval and pupal stages. Cockroaches, grasshoppers, and aphids have incomplete metamorphosis.

questions.question: The three classes in a termitarium are
questions.explanation: The primary castes in a termite colony are the workers, soldiers, and reproductives (including the queen and king).

questions.question: The ability of the cockroach to live in cracks and crevices is enhanced by the possession of
questions.explanation: The dorso-ventrally flattened body shape of a cockroach is a key adaptation that allows it to easily hide and move in narrow spaces.

questions.question: The case of termites that lacks pigmentation is the
questions.explanation: Workers are the most numerous caste and are unpigmented, which gives them a whitish appearance, leading to their common name 'white ants'.

questions.question: In the honey bee colony, the drones are
options: A. sterile male with reduced mouth parts
B. Sterile male with well developed mouth parts
C. fertile males with reduced mouth parts
D. fertile males with well-developed mouth parts.
questions.explanation: Drones are fertile male bees with the sole function of mating with the queen. They have poorly developed mouthparts as they are fed by worker bees.

questions.question: The group of Arthropods that has no antennae is the
questions.explanation: Arachnida (spiders, scorpions, etc.) is the class of arthropods that lacks antennae. The others listed (crustaceans, centipedes, millipedes) all have antennae.

questions.question: The structure labeled II Is used for
questions.explanation: Structure II is the antenna, a key sensory organ for feeling and sensing the environment.

questions.question: The structure labelled III represents the
questions.explanation: Structure III is the proboscis, a mouthpart adapted for sponging or lapping liquid food, as seen in the housefly.

questions.question: The part that will develop into an organ for feeling is labelled
questions.explanation: Part I represents the head region of the pupa, which will develop the antennae used for feeling in the adult stage.

questions.question: The part labelled II is the
questions.explanation: Part II is the silk thread, which forms a girdle that supports the pupa (chrysalis) and attaches it to a surface.

questions.question: The jointed organ ln insects that bears organs which are sensitive to touch, smell and vibration is the
questions.explanation: The antennae are the primary sensory organs of insects, detecting touch, smell, and vibrations.

questions.question: Water fleas, woodlice and barnacles belong to the group
questions.explanation: Water fleas, woodlice, and barnacles are all members of the class Crustacea, which are primarily aquatic arthropods.

questions.question: The role of the male adult honey bee is to
questions.explanation: The sole function of a male honey bee (drone) is to mate with the queen. All other tasks are performed by the sterile female workers.

questions.question: When oil is poured into the breeding site of mosquitoes, it
options: A. Deprives the larva of water
questions.explanation: The oil film on the water surface prevents mosquito larvae and pupae from reaching the air to breathe through their siphons, causing them to suffocate.

questions.question: A feature of the caste systems of bees and termites is that
options: B. the kings are bigger than the queens
C. only the worker perform duties
D. nuptial fight is performed by all members
questions.explanation: In both bee and termite societies, the worker caste is sterile and cannot reproduce. This is a key feature of social insects.

questions.question: 'Jointed Skeleton' is absent in the
questions.explanation: A snail, a mollusc, does not have a jointed skeleton. All other organisms listed are arthropods with jointed skeletons (exoskeletons).

questions.question: Insects are considered the most successful among the invertebrates because they
options: B. Survive in various environmental conditions
D. Possess the ability to change their forms
questions.explanation: The ability of insects to thrive in a vast range of habitats and environmental conditions, due to various adaptations, makes them the most successful group of invertebrates.

questions.question: The larval stage of a mosquito is called
questions.explanation: The aquatic larval stage of a mosquito is commonly known as a wriggler due to its wriggling movement in water.

questions.question: The function of the long-winged reproductive in a termite colony is to
questions.explanation: The primary function of the long-winged reproductives is to fly out of the colony in a swarm to establish new colonies, thus dispersing the population.

questions.question: The stage in the life history of the moth responsible for the destruction of agricultural crops is the
questions.explanation: The caterpillar is the larval stage of a moth and is the primary feeding stage that causes damage to crops.

questions.question: The only caste in the termite colony whose members can feed themselves are the
questions.explanation: Workers are the only caste in a termite colony with the ability to digest cellulose and feed themselves. They also provide food for all other castes.

questions.question: The maxillary palp is labeled
questions.explanation: Based on the diagram, IV represents the maxillary palp, which is a sensory appendage near the mouthparts of the cockroach.

questions.question: The structure labeled I is sensitive to
questions.explanation: Structure I is the antenna, which has sensory receptors for both chemicals (smell) and touch.

questions.question: The process of shedding the exoskeleton of an arthropod is known as
questions.explanation: The process of molting, or ecdysis, is the periodic shedding of the exoskeleton to allow the arthropod to grow.

questions.question: Which of the following is common to the mosquito, housefly and blackfly?
options: B. They are parasites of man
C. Their immature stages are aquatic
D. The adults have two o pairs of wings
questions.explanation: Mosquitoes, houseflies, and blackflies all undergo complete metamorphosis, which involves distinct egg, larval, pupal, and adult stages.

questions.question: The most abundant group of organisms in the animal kingdom is
questions.explanation: The class Insecta is the most numerous group of organisms, comprising over 70% of all known animal species.

questions.question: Which of the following animals is most adapted for water conservation?
questions.explanation: Insects are highly adapted for water conservation due to their waxy cuticle and efficient excretory system that produces uric acid, which is nearly water-free.

questions.question: The main distinguishing features between the soldier termite and other members of the caste are the
options: A. presence of wings, possession of a large thorax and a small head
B. absence of wings, possession of strong mandibles and a large head
C. absence of wings, possession of big head and the absence of mandible
D. presence of wings, possession of a small head and large thorax.
questions.explanation: Soldier termites are wingless, but they have a large head and strong mandibles for defense, distinguishing them from the other castes.

questions.question: Which of the organisms represented are notable agricultural pests?
questions.explanation: Organism I (grasshopper) and IV (caterpillar) are well-known agricultural pests that feed on crops.

questions.question: An economic importance of the organism represented by IV Is that
options: A. Its faeces pollutes drinking water
B. It helps in the control of mosquito larvae
C. it transmits water-borne diseases to humans
D. it is destructive to farm crops
questions.explanation: Organism IV (caterpillar) is destructive to farm crops because it is a voracious feeder on plant leaves during its larval stage.

questions.question: The adult form of II is a vector of
questions.explanation: Organism II is a mosquito pupa (tumbler). The adult mosquito is a vector for filariasis, which can lead to elephantiasis.

questions.question: The adaptive importance of nuptial flight from termite colonies is to
options: A. ensure cross-breeding between members of one colony to another
B. expel the reproductive so as to provide enough food for other members
C. disperse the reproductive in order to establish new colonies
D. provide abundant food for birds and other animals during the early rains
questions.explanation: Nuptial flight allows the winged reproductives to disperse from their parent colony, find mates, and establish new, independent colonies.

questions.question: An arthropod that is destructive at the early stage of its life cycle is
questions.explanation: The butterfly's larval stage (caterpillar) is destructive to plants, whereas the adult is beneficial for pollination.

questions.question: The significance of a very large number of termites involved in nuptial swarming is to
options: A. provide birds with plenty of food
B. ensure their perpetuation despite predatory pressure
C. search for a favourable place to breed
D. ensure that every individual gets a mate.
questions.explanation: The sheer number of termites in a swarm increases the chances that enough individuals will survive predation to establish new colonies and ensure the species' perpetuation.

questions.question: Which of the following describes a characteristic of arthropods?
options: A. The organism has a pair of jointed appendages
B. The body is not divided into a number of segments
C. The body is covered by chitin
D. The organism finds it easy to grow freely.
questions.explanation: The presence of a chitinous exoskeleton is a fundamental characteristic of all arthropods. This exoskeleton must be shed for growth, so they do not grow freely.

questions.question: Which of the following distinguishes a butterfly from a moth?
options: A. Moth are active during the day
C. The abdomen of a moth is fatter than that of a butterfly
D. The wings of a butterfly rest horizontally but those of a moth rest vertically.
questions.explanation: Moths typically have fatter, hairier bodies and abdomens compared to butterflies. Moths are also usually nocturnal and have different antennae and wing-resting positions.

questions.question: Proboscis is a structure that is mostly found in
questions.explanation: A proboscis is a tube-like mouthpart used for feeding, found in various insects like butterflies and mosquitoes.

Classification of Verterbrate: Pisces, A.name: Classification of Verterbrate: Pisces, Amphibians & Reptiles

questions.question: The part numbered 12 is
questions.explanation: The part labeled 12 on the fish diagram is the operculum, which is also known as the opercular plate or gill cover. It protects the gills.

questions.question: During the movement of the fish from point A to target B, one of these parts is not involved
questions.explanation: Part 10 represents the scales, which are part of the fish's outer covering (exoskeleton) and are not directly involved in the propulsion or steering of the fish. The other labeled parts (fins and lateral line) are all involved in locomotion and sensing movement.

questions.question: The feature that distinguishes the toad or frog from a fish is the absence of
questions.explanation: Toads and frogs, as amphibians, have smooth or warty skin but lack scales. Fish are characterized by having scales. Both groups possess lungs (in adult amphibians), paired appendages, a tail (in fish and some amphibians), and skin glands.

questions.question: Which of these is not associated with the tadpole stages of the toad or frog?
questions.explanation: Toad and frog eggs are laid in a jelly-like mass without a hard shell. The tadpole stage is characterized by the presence of a V-shaped gland for attachment, external gills which are later replaced by internal gills, and a developing operculum.

questions.question: Some of the feature of an animal are scales, teeth, nares and backbone. The animal is likely to be a
questions.explanation: A lizard is a reptile that has scales, teeth (homodont dentition), nostrils (nares), and a backbone. Toads and birds lack scales, and birds and some mammals (like rats) have teeth, but not scales.

questions.question: Which of the following animals is cold-blooded?
questions.explanation: A lizard is a reptile and is poikilothermic (cold-blooded), meaning its body temperature fluctuates with the surrounding environment. The other animals listed (cat, whale, bird, horse) are homeothermic (warm-blooded).

questions.question: The main function of the swim-ladder is for
questions.explanation: The swim bladder is a gas-filled organ found in bony fish that allows them to control their buoyancy and maintain a stable position at a specific depth in the water column.

questions.question: When an operculate fish breathes It takes in water through the
options: A. mouth and passes it out through the same way
B. mouth and passes it out through the operculum
C. operculum and passes It out through the mouth
D. operculum and passes it out through the nostrils
E. nostrils and passes It out through the operculum.
questions.explanation: An operculate fish takes in water through its mouth. As the mouth closes, water is forced over the gills and then exits through the operculum, allowing for efficient gas exchange.

questions.question: Which of the following structures Is NOT found in the female Agama lizard.
questions.explanation: Pre-anal pads (not pre-natal pads) are found on male Agama lizards and are used for grasping during mating. Females lack this structure. The other options are present in both sexes.

questions.question: The male toad differs from the female by having
questions.explanation: Male toads possess vocal sacs, which they inflate to produce loud croaking sounds to attract mates. This feature is absent in female toads.

questions.question: The dorsal and anal fins of fish are used for
questions.explanation: The dorsal and anal fins are unpaired fins located on the top and bottom of the fish, respectively. Their primary function is to provide stability and prevent the fish from rolling (controlling rolling movements).

questions.question: In fish the sense organs which detect movements In the water are located within the
questions.explanation: The lateral line system, a row of sensory pores running along the sides of a fish's body, is used to detect water movements, vibrations, and pressure changes.

questions.question: At what stage in the life history of a toad is its mode of breathing similar to that of a fish?
questions.explanation: During the tadpole stage, the toad develops internal gills, which function like a fish's gills to extract dissolved oxygen from water. This is the stage where their breathing is most similar to a fish's.

questions.question: Fishes are cold-coded because their body temperature is
options: C. dependent on that of their surrounding
questions.explanation: Fishes are cold-blooded (poikilothermic) because they cannot regulate their own body temperature internally; it changes with the temperature of their aquatic environment.

questions.question: The fins making limbs of the bony fish are
questions.explanation: The pectoral fins and pelvic fins are the paired fins of a fish, which are considered to be homologous to the forelimbs and hind limbs of other vertebrates.

questions.question: The long and coiled Intestine of a young tadpole is an adaptation to its
questions.explanation: Young tadpoles are herbivores, and their long, coiled intestines are an adaptation for digesting plant matter, which requires a longer time to break down than animal protein.

questions.question: The major function of the swim-bladder in fishes is
questions.explanation: The primary function of the swim bladder is to regulate the fish's buoyancy, allowing it to maintain its position in the water column without sinking or rising.

questions.question: Which of the following animals has homodont dentition?
questions.explanation: A lizard has homodont dentition, meaning all its teeth are of a similar shape and size. Mammals like rats and humans have heterodont dentition, with different types of teeth for different functions. Pigeons (birds) have no teeth.

questions.question: In which of the following does external fertilization take place?
questions.explanation: Toads, like most amphibians, undergo external fertilization where the female lays eggs in water and the male fertilizes them externally. Lizards, birds, and cockroaches have internal fertilization.

questions.question: The structure labelled 4 is for
questions.explanation: Structure 4 is the long, coiled intestine of the tadpole, which is part of the digestive system and is used for feeding and nutrient absorption.

questions.question: As the tadpoles develops, the structure labelled 5
questions.explanation: Structure 5 is the tadpole's tail. As the tadpole undergoes metamorphosis, its tail is gradually absorbed and becomes shorter until it disappears completely in the adult toad.

questions.question: The gill rakers of fishes take part in
questions.explanation: Gill rakers are bony projections on the gill arch that function as strainers to prevent food particles from entering the gill filaments and aid in feeding.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct order of the development stages?
questions.explanation: The correct sequence of development is: 5 (egg mass) -> 3 (young tadpole with external gills) -> 2 (tadpole with internal gills and hind limbs) -> 1 (tadpole with all four limbs and tail) -> 4 (adult).

questions.question: Stage 3 breathes
questions.explanation: Stage 3 represents the early tadpole with external gills, which it uses to breathe dissolved oxygen from the water.

questions.question: Cold blooded animals are referred to as
questions.explanation: The scientific term for cold-blooded animals is poikilothermic. Homeothermic refers to warm-blooded animals that can maintain a constant body temperature.

questions.question: Which of the organism has lost the pentadactyl limb structure?
questions.explanation: The pentadactyl limb, with its five-digit structure, is a characteristic of all tetrapods (four-limbed vertebrates). Fish are not tetrapods and possess fins instead of limbs.

questions.question: Which of the following combinations differentiates a bony fish from a cartilaginous fish?
questions.explanation: Bony fish are differentiated by the absence of visible gill slits (II), having a bony skeleton (III), and a laterally compressed body (IV). Cartilaginous fish have visible gill slits, a cartilaginous skeleton, and a dorso-ventrally flattened body.

questions.question: Which is the most important adaptation of a bony fish to life in water?
options: A. The possession of a streamlined shape
B. The presence of overlapping scales
C. The covering of the body by thin film of shine.
D. The possession of a caudal fin.
questions.explanation: The streamlined body shape is the most crucial adaptation for aquatic life, as it reduces drag and allows for efficient movement through water.

questions.question: In which of the following vertebrates does the skin function as a respiratory surface?
questions.explanation: A frog's skin is highly vascularized and permeable, allowing it to function as a respiratory surface for cutaneous respiration, especially when it is submerged in water.

questions.question: In which of the following groups of vertebrates would the largest amount of yolk be found in the egg?
questions.explanation: Reptilian eggs have a large amount of yolk to nourish the developing embryo, as the eggs are laid on land and the embryo must complete its development before hatching.

questions.question: The structures that prevent food particles from escaping through the fish gills are called gills.
questions.explanation: Gill rakers are finger-like projections on the gill arches that act as a sieve to prevent food particles from passing through the gills during breathing.

questions.question: The possession of scales, laying of eggs with shells and bony structure of the head are characteristics shared by
questions.explanation: Both birds and reptiles lay eggs with shells and have scales (on birds' legs). They also share a bony head structure. Fish have scales but lay soft eggs without hard shells, and molluscs are invertebrates.

questions.question: The key event in the transition of the amphibians from water to land Is the
options: A. replacement of the gills with lungs
C. development of long hind D. limbs
D. limbs E. possession of tympanic membrane
questions.explanation: The evolution of lungs to replace gills was the crucial event that allowed amphibians to breathe air and survive on land, marking the transition from a fully aquatic life to a semi-terrestrial one.

questions.question: The set of fins that controls steering, balancing and change of direction and pitch in fish is
questions.explanation: The pectoral and pelvic fins are the paired fins that function as hydrofoils, allowing the fish to steer, balance, and control its pitch and direction.

questions.question: Amphibians are normally found
options: A. on dry land and in water
B. In water and on moist land
questions.explanation: Amphibians have a dual habitat. They live in water or on moist land because their skin is susceptible to drying out, and they typically return to water to reproduce.

questions.question: The correct evolutionary sequence of the organisms represented is
questions.explanation: The correct evolutionary sequence of vertebrates, from oldest to most recent, is: IV (Fish) -> II (Amphibian) -> III (Reptile) -> I (Mammal).

questions.question: Ovoviparity is the type of fertilization exhibited by the organism labelled.
questions.explanation: Ovoviviparity, where the young develop in eggs that hatch inside the mother's body, is a type of reproduction found in some fish, such as the guppy (IV), which gives birth to live young.

questions.question: The presence of endoskeleton is characteristic of
questions.explanation: The presence of an internal skeleton (endoskeleton) is the defining characteristic that separates vertebrates from invertebrates.

questions.question: A noticeable adaptation of the Water animal to its aquatic habitat is the possession of
questions.explanation: Webbed digits are a key adaptation for aquatic animals, as they increase the surface area of the limbs, making them more effective paddles for swimming.

questions.question: The processes of water loss and intake indicated by the arrows labelled I and II are respectively
questions.explanation: In amphibians on land, water is lost through evaporation from the skin (I). When in water, they take in water through osmosis (II) due to the concentration gradient.

questions.question: I. Rattus rattus II. Agama agama III. Bufo regularis IV. Tilapia zilli. The order of evolutionary advancement of the above vertebrates is
questions.explanation: The correct evolutionary order is from the most primitive to the most advanced: Tilapia zilli (fish) -> Bufo regularis (amphibian) -> Agama agama (reptile) -> Rattus rattus (mammal).

questions.question: The main function of the caudal fin in Tilapia is to
options: A. propel it forward in water
B. steer it while changing direction
D. enable it to float in water.
questions.explanation: The caudal fin, or tail fin, is the primary fin responsible for generating thrust and propelling the fish forward through the water.

questions.question: In lizards, the lowering of the gular fold is used to
questions.explanation: Male lizards lower and display their gular fold (throat fan) as part of a visual display to attract females for mating.

questions.question: An example of a fish that aestivates is
questions.explanation: Lungfish are a unique type of fish that can survive periods of drought by burrowing into the mud and entering a state of dormancy called aestivation, breathing air with their modified swim bladders (lungs).

questions.question: The diagram shows that the organisms are
questions.explanation: The diagram illustrates a toad laying eggs in water, a characteristic of oviparous animals that reproduce by laying eggs that hatch outside the body.

questions.question: The breeding posture illustrated in the diagram is known as;
questions.explanation: The breeding posture where the male grasps the female from behind is called amplexus. This position ensures that the male is properly positioned to fertilize the eggs as the female lays them.

questions.question: Which of the following is used mainly for balancing in fish?
questions.explanation: The dorsal fin is the primary fin used for balancing, preventing the fish from rolling from side to side and maintaining its upright position.

questions.question: The most important characteristic that makes reptiles to conquer terrestrial habitats is the possession of
questions.explanation: The amniotic egg, with its protective shell and internal membranes, was the critical innovation that allowed reptiles to reproduce on land without needing to return to water, thus fully conquering terrestrial habitats.

questions.question: The first terrestrial vertebrates evolved from
questions.explanation: The first terrestrial vertebrates were amphibians, which evolved from an ancestral group of lobe-finned fish (Pisces).

questions.question: The feature that makes locomotion in water easy for fish is the
questions.explanation: A streamlined body shape is a hydrodynamic adaptation that reduces water resistance, making it easier for fish to move through their aquatic environment.

questions.question: With respect to their decreasing dependence on aquatic conditions for reproduction, which of the following is the correct arrangements of the animals represented?
options: A. IV, III, II and I
B. I, II, IV, and III
C. III, II, IV and I
D. I, IV, II and III
questions.explanation: The correct evolutionary order of decreasing dependence on water for reproduction is: IV (Fish, which lay eggs in water) -> III (Amphibian, which lay eggs in water) -> II (Reptile, which lay amniotic eggs on land) -> I (Mammal, which give live birth).

questions.question: Which if the animals represents the oldest creatures in terms of evolutionary history?
questions.explanation: The diagram shows a fish (IV). Fish are the most primitive and oldest group of vertebrates, from which all other vertebrates are believed to have evolved.

questions.question: The function of the red head in male Agama lizards is to
options: A. attract female lizards for mating purposes
B. warn predators of the distastefulness of the animal
C. conceal and camouflage the animal from predators
D. scare other males from the territory.
questions.explanation: The red head of a male Agama lizard is a visual signal used during courtship to attract females for mating. It is also used to intimidate other males.

questions.question: The basking of Agama lizards in the sun is to
options: A. change the colour of their body
B. raise their body temperature to become active
C. fight to defend their territories
D. attract the female for courtship.
questions.explanation: As a poikilothermic (cold-blooded) animal, the Agama lizard basks in the sun to absorb heat. This raises its body temperature to an optimal level for metabolic activity, enabling it to become active for hunting, mating, and other behaviors.

questions.question: An example of poikilothermic organisms is
questions.explanation: A lizard is a reptile and is a poikilothermic (cold-blooded) animal. Rabbits and birds are homeothermic (warm-blooded), and a cockroach is also poikilothermic, but the lizard is the best example among the vertebrates listed.

questions.question: A trawler on a fishing trip landed a type of animal with hairs on its body. This animal could have been
questions.explanation: Hair is a unique and defining characteristic of mammals. Amphibians and reptiles have scales or smooth skin, sharks are cartilaginous fish, and seagulls are birds with feathers.

questions.question: Which of these is not a part of the feather of a bird?
questions.explanation: The wing is the entire forelimb of a bird, not a component of an individual feather. A feather is composed of a quill, rachis, barbs, barbules, vane, and in some cases, an aftershaft and an inferior umbilicus.

questions.question: Which of these animals is NOT metamerically segmented?
questions.explanation: Metameric segmentation refers to the repetition of body parts along the length of the body. Tapeworms, earthworms, centipedes, and crayfish are segmented. A shark, a vertebrate, is not metamerically segmented in the same way.

questions.question: An homoiothermic animal kept in a room where the temperature is lower than the body temperature may lose heat by four physical processes. Which of the following processes is NOT connected with body temperature regulation?
questions.explanation: Sweat is a substance produced by the body, not a physical process of heat loss. The physical processes of heat loss are radiation, conduction, convection, and evaporation (of sweat). The process of sweating is a biological response, but the heat loss is due to the evaporation of the sweat.

questions.question: Fig1 represents a quill feather. The structure labelled 'M' is the
questions.explanation: In a quill feather, the rachis (shaft) has two openings. The inferior umbilicus is the opening at the base, while the superior umbilicus is a small opening on the underside where the rachis begins, often associated with the aftershaft.

questions.question: The young chick is formed from
questions.explanation: The young chick develops from the **germinal disc** (labeled 2), which contains the genetic material and is the site of embryonic development after fertilization.

questions.question: Which parts provide food for the developing chick?
questions.explanation: The **yolk** (3) and **albumen** (4, or egg white) are the primary sources of nutrients and water for the developing chick. The yolk provides fats, proteins, and vitamins, while the albumen provides proteins and water.

questions.question: Which of the following adaptations is NOT concerned with the flight of birds?
questions.explanation: Webbed feet are an adaptation for swimming in aquatic birds, not for flight. The other options are all adaptations that facilitate flight, such as a streamlined shape, strong flight muscles, reduced body weight (hollow bones), and a broad sternum for muscle attachment.

questions.question: In mammals, the function of the sebaceous gland is to
options: E. manufacture vitamin D. for the skin.
questions.explanation: Sebaceous glands secrete an oily substance called sebum. Sebum lubricates and waterproofs the hair and skin, keeping them supple and protected.

questions.question: For effective functioning of a bird's quill feather, hooks fit on the ridges of the
questions.explanation: The vane of a feather is made up of barbs, which in turn have smaller filaments called barbules. The barbules have microscopic hooks that interlock with the barbules of adjacent barbs, creating a smooth, strong, and cohesive surface essential for flight.

questions.question: A feature which adapts birds to flight is the possession of
questions.explanation: Birds have hollow, lightweight bones that reduce their overall body weight, which is a crucial adaptation for flight. The other options are not unique to birds or are not direct adaptations for flight.

questions.question: In which of the following organisms would glycogen be stored?
questions.explanation: Glycogen is the primary storage form of glucose in animals, while plants store glucose as starch. Rattus is a mammal (animal), so it stores glycogen. Spirogyra, Chlamydomonas, and Magnifera are plants or algae and would store starch.

questions.question: Birds maintain their body temperature with the help of their
options: A. blood which maintains constant temperature
B. feathers which cover the body
D. veins which transport fluid of constant temperature to all body tissues.
questions.explanation: Feathers provide excellent insulation, trapping a layer of air close to the bird's body and helping to conserve heat. This is a key adaptation for maintaining a constant high body temperature.

questions.question: The mammalian organ which acts as a digestive and as an endocrine organ is the
questions.explanation: The pancreas has both exocrine (digestive) and endocrine functions. It produces digestive enzymes that are secreted into the small intestine and hormones (like insulin and glucagon) that are secreted directly into the bloodstream.

questions.question: A distinguishing feature of mammals is the possession of
questions.explanation: Hair or fur is a defining characteristic of mammals. While other animals may have skin, scales (reptiles, fish), or nails (birds, reptiles), only mammals have hair.

questions.question: In dissection, the rib cage of a mammal has to be opened in order to expose the
questions.explanation: The heart is located within the thoracic cavity, which is enclosed and protected by the rib cage. The liver and diaphragm are located in the abdominal cavity, and the sternum is part of the rib cage itself.

questions.question: In mammals, the organ which performs digestive and endocrine functions is the
questions.explanation: The pancreas produces digestive enzymes (exocrine function) and hormones such as insulin and glucagon (endocrine function), making it both a digestive and an endocrine organ.

questions.question: A characteristic of vertebrates that is unique to mammals is
options: A. the presence of pentadactyl limbs
questions.explanation: While many vertebrates have pentadactyl limbs, show parental care, and have pulmonary circulation, the presence of a scrotum (a sac that holds the testes outside the body) is a unique characteristic of male mammals.

questions.question: Complex social behaviour and organization are found mostly in
questions.explanation: While some insects and birds show social behavior, mammals, especially primates like humans, are known for the most complex social structures, communication, and intelligence.

questions.question: Viviparity occurs mainly in the
questions.explanation: Viviparity, or giving birth to live young that have developed inside the mother's body, is the dominant mode of reproduction in mammals, although it also occurs in some other animal groups.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of organs is located in the anterior half of the mammalian body cavity?
questions.explanation: The anterior half of the mammalian body cavity is the thoracic cavity, which contains the lungs and heart. The kidneys and ovaries are located in the posterior (abdominal) cavity.

questions.question: A peculiar characteristics of mammals is that they
questions.explanation: While other vertebrates can have teeth, be warm-blooded, or have lungs, the presence of sebaceous glands (which secrete oil to waterproof the skin) is a characteristic unique to mammals.

questions.question: The eggs of birds contain relatively larger quantities of yolk than those of amphibians and reptiles because
options: A. birds are generally bigger in size
B. embryonic development is longer in birds
C. those of birds are fertilized internally
questions.explanation: Birds' eggs contain a larger yolk because the embryonic development period is longer, and the embryo needs a large, self-contained food source to sustain its growth until it hatches.

questions.question: A unique characteristic that distinguishes the class of vertebrates represented from other vertebrates is the presence of
options: B. scales on the lower legs
questions.explanation: The presence of a covering of feathers is a defining and unique characteristic of the class Aves (birds).

questions.question: The structures used for offence and defense are labeled
questions.explanation: The structures labeled I (claws on legs) and II (beak/bill) are used by birds for both offense and defense, as well as for feeding.

questions.question: A characteristic that exemplifies the evolutionary advancement of mammals over other vertebrates is the
questions.explanation: While paired limbs, a terrestrial life, and a heart are found in many vertebrates, the viviparous mode of reproduction, which involves live birth and direct maternal nourishment, is a highly advanced evolutionary trait most prevalent in mammals.

questions.question: Which of the following produces both hormones and enzymes?
questions.explanation: The pancreas is a 'mixed' gland that produces both digestive enzymes (exocrine function) and hormones like insulin and glucagon (endocrine function).

questions.question: The part of a domestic fowl responsible for preventing heat loss is the
questions.explanation: Down feathers are small, soft, fluffy feathers that grow close to the skin. They are an excellent insulator and are primarily responsible for trapping a layer of air to prevent heat loss.

questions.question: Parental care is exhibited by
questions.explanation: Birds are well-known for their extensive parental care, including building nests, incubating eggs, and feeding and protecting their young. Snails, earthworms, and toads generally do not exhibit parental care.

questions.question: The main function of the feathers covering the part labeled I is to
options: A. generate heat to keep the animal
B. provide some warm power for flight
C. severe as insulator to maintain body heat
D. prevent ecto parasites from attacking the animal.
questions.explanation: The feathers covering the body (part I) are a combination of contour and down feathers, and their main function is to serve as an insulator, helping to maintain the bird's body heat.

questions.question: Based on the shape and structure of the beak and feet, the bird represented is likely to feed mainly on
questions.explanation: The bird's hooked beak and sharp, curved talons are characteristic adaptations of a raptor, or a bird of prey, which feeds primarily on flesh.

questions.question: In which of the following groups of vertebrates is parental care mostly exhibited?
questions.explanation: While parental care exists in birds, reptiles, and amphibians, it is most highly developed and prolonged in mammals, especially with the unique feature of mammary glands for feeding the young.

questions.question: Which of the following possesses mammary gland?
questions.explanation: A whale is a mammal, and the defining characteristic of mammals is the presence of mammary glands to produce milk for their young. The other options are fish, which do not have mammary glands.

questions.question: The feature that links birds to reptiles In evolution is the possession of
questions.explanation: A key piece of evidence linking birds and reptiles is the presence of scales on the lower legs and feet of birds, which are homologous to the scales found on reptiles.

questions.question: Which of the following types of feathers is used for flight in birds?
questions.explanation: Quill feathers, also known as flight feathers, are the long, stiff feathers found on the wings and tail of a bird. They are essential for flight.
